xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: CIS Google Chrome Benchmark

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This document provides prescriptive guidance for establishing a secure configuration posture for Google Chrome Browser. This guide was tested against Google Chrome v75. To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org. If you have questions, comments, or have identified ways to improve this guide, please write us at feedback@cisecurity.org.

xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:notice: BACKGROUND. The Center for Internet Security ("CIS") provides benchmarks, scoring tools, software, data, information, suggestions, ideas, and other services and materials from the CIS website or elsewhere ("Products") as a public service to Internet users worldwide. Recommendations contained in the Products ("Recommendations") result from a consensus-building process that involves many security experts and are generally generic in nature. The Recommendations are intended to provide helpful information to organizations attempting to evaluate or improve the security of their networks, systems, and devices. Proper use of the Recommendations requires careful analysis and adaptation to specific user requirements. The Recommendations are not in any way intended to be a "quick fix" for anyone's information security needs. NO REPRESENTATIONS, WARRANTIES, OR COVENANTS. CIS makes no representations, warranties, or covenants whatsoever as to (i) the positive or negative effect of the Products or the Recommendations on the operation or the security of any particular network, computer system, network device, software, hardware, or any component of any of the foregoing or (ii) the accuracy, reliability, timeliness, or completeness of the Products or the Recommendations. CIS is providing the Products and the Recommendations "as is" and "as available" without representations, warranties, or covenants of any kind. USER AGREEMENTS. By using the Products and/or the Recommendations, I and/or my organization ("We") agree and acknowledge that: 1. No network, system, device, hardware, software, or component can be made fully secure; 2. We are using the Products and the Recommendations solely at our own risk; 3. We are not compensating CIS to assume any liabilities associated with our use of the Products or the Recommendations, even risks that result from CIS's negligence or failure to perform; 4. Neither CIS, nor any CIS Party (defined below) has any responsibility to make any corrections, updates, upgrades, or bug fixes; or to notify us of the need for any such corrections, updates, upgrades, or bug fixes; and 6. Neither CIS nor any CIS Party has or will have any liability to us whatsoever (whether based in contract, tort, strict liability or otherwise) for any direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, or special damages (including without limitation loss of profits, loss of sales, loss of or damage to reputation,loss of customers, loss of software, data, information or emails, loss of privacy, loss of use of any computer or other equipment, business interruption, wasted management or other staff resources or claims of any kind against us from third parties) arising out of or in any way Connected with our use of or our inability to use any of the Products or Recommendations (even if CIS has been advised of the possibility of such damages), including without limitation any liability associated with infringement of intellectual property, defects, bugs, errors, omissions, viruses, worms, backdoors, Trojan horses or other harmful items. GRANT OF LIMITED RIGHTS. CIS hereby grants each user the following rights, but only so long as the user complies with all of the terms of these Agreed Terms of Use: 1. We acknowledge and agree that we are not acquiring title to any intellectual property rights in the Products and that full title and all ownership rights to the Products will remain the exclusive property of CIS or CIS Parties. xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Items in this profile intend to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: be the starting baseline for most organizations;
provide a clear security benefit; and
not inhibit the utility of the technology beyond acceptable means.

xccdf:Profile.xccdf:title: Level 2 (L2) - High Security/Sensitive Data Environment (limited functionality)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This profile extends the "Level 1 (L1)" profile. Items in this profile exhibit one or more of the following characteristics:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: are intended for environments or use cases where security is more critical than manageability and usability;
may negatively inhibit the utility or performance of the technology; and
limit the ability of remote management/access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Note: Implementation of Level 2 requires that both Level 1 and Level 2 settings are applied.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable firewall traversal from remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostFirewallTraversal' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostAllowClientPairing' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable PIN-less authentication for remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostAllowClientPairing' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostAllowRelayedConnection' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable the use of relay servers by the remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'." -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostAllowRelayedConnection' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure '\d+' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '.*'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Configure the required domain names for remote access clients' is set to 'Enabled' with a domain defined" -> "Ensure '\d+' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '.*'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CloudPrintSubmitEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable submission of documents to Google Cloud print' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'CloudPrintSubmitEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ImportSavedPasswords' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Import saved passwords from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'ImportSavedPasswords' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AutofillCreditCardEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill for credit cards' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'AutofillCreditCardEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AutofillAddressEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill for addresses' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'AutofillAddressEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that are configured by default when you install Google Chrome. Enforcing these settings at an enterprise level can prevent these settings from changing to a less secure option.

This section contains recommendations related to Remote Access that are configured by default when you install Google Chrome. Enforcing these settings at an enterprise level can prevent these settings from changing to a less secure option.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable curtaining of remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows controls to prevent someone physically present at the host machine from seeing what a user is doing while a remote connection is in progress.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If a remote session is in progress the user physically present at the host machine shall be able to see what a remote user is doing.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable curtaining of remote access hosts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, host's physical input and output devices are enabled while a remote connection is in progress.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow gnubby authentication for remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to proxy gnubby authentication requests (U2F) across a remote host connection.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Proxying shall not be used to circumvent firewall restrictions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Allow gnubby authentication for remote access hosts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, gnubby authentication requests will not be proxied.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow remote users to interact with elevated windows in remote assistance sessions' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to run the remote assistance host in a process with uiAccess permissions. This allows remote users to interact with elevated windows on the local user's desktop.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote users shall not be able to escalate privileges.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Allow remote users to interact with elevated windows in remote assistance sessions
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, the remote assistance host will run in the user's context. Furthermore, remote users cannot interact with elevated windows on the desktop.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows for processes started while the browser is open to remain running once the browser has been closed. It also allows for background apps and the current browsing session to remain active after the browser has been closed.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, vulnerable or malicious plugins, apps and processes can continue running even after Chrome has closed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this policy is set to Disabled, background mode is disabled and cannot be controlled by the user in the browser settings.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Ask where to save each file before downloading' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to download files automatically to the default download directory without prompting.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from the drive-by-downloads threat.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Ask where to save each file before downloading
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, users are always asked where to save each file before downloading.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable saving browser history' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to save the browser history.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser history shall be saved as it may contain indicators of compromise.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable saving browser history
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
All user browser history will be saved.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable HTTP/0.9 support on non-default ports' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Non-HTTP services' responses may be read via XHR as their response streams will be interpreted by Chrome as HTTP/0.9. This setting allows to enable HTTP/0.9 on ports other than 80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: DNS rebinding attacks can be mounted against non-HTTP services to steal their responses cross-protocol.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable HTTP/0.9 support on non-default ports
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, HTTP/0.9 will be disabled on non-default ports 80/443.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable component updates in Google Chrome' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome's Component Updater updates several components of Google Chrome (like the Adobe Flash Player, Widevine DRM, Chrome updater recovery component) on a regular basis.

notes:notes.xhtml:p: To check the current components versions navigate to chrome://components.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Chrome Updater shall be used to keep the components bundled to Chrome up-to-date.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable component updates in Google Chrome
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Google Chrome Updater keeps the components bundled to Chrome up-to-date.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable deprecated web platform features for a limited time' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the ability to re-enable specific deprecated web platform features for a defined period of time.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Deprecated web platform features shall no longer be used.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable deprecated web platform features for a limited time
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, deprecated web platform features are no longer being reactivated.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable third party software injection blocking' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to prevented third party software from injecting executable code into Chrome's processes.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Third party software shall not be able to inject executable code into Chrome's processes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable third party software injection blocking
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Third party software will be prevented from injecting executable code into Chrome's processes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Extend Flash content setting to all content' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Controls if all Flash content embedded on websites that have been set to allow Flash in content settings - either by the user or by enterprise policy - will be run, including content from other origins or small content.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Cross-domain Flash plugins or "hidden" flash content may be malicious and therefore shall be prevented from being displayed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extend Flash content setting to all content
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Flash content from other origins or small content might be blocked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Suppress the unsupported OS warning' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome will show a warning that appears when Google Chrome is running on a computer or operating system that is no longer supported.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The user shall be informed if the used software is no longer supported.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Suppress the unsupported OS warning
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Unsupported warnings will not be suppressed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Whether online OCSP/CRL checks are performed' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to reactivate soft-fail, online revocation checks although they provide no effective security benefit.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An attacker may block OCSP traffic and cause revocation checks to pass in order to cause usage of soft-fail behavior. Furthermore, the browser may leak what website is being accessed and who accesses it to CA servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Whether online OCSP/CRL checks are performed
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, unsecure online OCSP/CRL checks are no longer performed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow WebDriver to Override Incompatible Policies' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The WebDriver feature may override policies which can interfere with its operation. At time of writing this may affect the policies 'Enable Site Isolation for every site' and 'Enable Site Isolation for specified origins'.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Settings of policies shall not be circumvented by any features.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow WebDriver to Override Incompatible Policies
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
WebDriver will not be allowed to override incompatible policies.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control SafeSites adult content filtering' is set to 'Enabled' with value 'Do not filter sites for adult content' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to use the Google Safe Search API to classify URLs as pornographic or not.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using Googles Safe Search API may leak information which is typed/pasted by mistake into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value Do not filter sites for adult content specified:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Control SafeSites adult content filtering.
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Sites will not be filtered.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Origins or hostname patterns for which restrictions on insecure origins should not apply' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to specify a list of origins (URLs) or hostname patterns (such as "*.example.com") for which security restrictions on insecure origins will not apply and are prevented from being labeled as "Not Secure" in the omnibox.

notes:notes.xhtml:p: This policy will override policy 'Origins or hostname patterns for which restrictions on insecure origins should not apply' UnsafelyTreatInsecureOriginAsSecure(deprecated in M69).

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Insecure contexts shall always be labeled as insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Origins or hostname patterns for which restrictions on insecure origins should not apply
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Insecure contexts are labeled as insecure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to disable the enforcing of Certificate Transparency requirements for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Legacy Certificate Authorities shall follow the Certificate Transparency policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, certificates not properly publicly disclosed as required by Certificate Transparency are untrusted.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of URLs' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to specify URLs/hostnames for which Certificate Transparency will not be enforced.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates that are required to be disclosed via Certificate Transparency shall be treated for all URLs as untrusted if they are not disclosed according to the Certificate Transparency policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of URLs
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, no URLs are excluded from Certificate Transparency requirements.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to exclude certificates by their subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes from enforcing Certificate Transparency requirements.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificate Transparency requirements shall be enforced for all certificates.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, no certificates are excluded from Certificate Transparency requirements.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that help reduce the overall attack surface. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within the environment since they restrict some browser functionality.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Default Flash Setting' is set to 'Enabled' (Click to Play)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to set whether websites are allowed to automatically run plugins. Automatically running plugins can be either allowed for all websites or denied for all websites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious plugins can cause browser instability and erratic behavior so setting the value to 'Click to play' will allow a user to only run necessary plugins.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Click to play selected from the drop down.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default Flash Setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, users must click plugins to allow their execution

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default notification setting' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers websites to display desktop notifications. These are push messages which are sent from the website operator through Google infrastructure to Chrome.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the website operator decides to send messages unencrypted Google's servers may process it as plain text. Furthermore, potentially compromised or faked notifications might trick users into clicking on a malicious link.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications selected from the drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default notification setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled and set to Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications, notifications will not be displayed for any sites and the user will not be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Control use of the Web Bluetooth API' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers a API which allows the access to nearby Bluetooth devices from the browser with users consent.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A malicious website could exploit a vulnerable Bluetooth device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API selected from the drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Control use of the Web Bluetooth API
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled and set to Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API, websites no longer can access nearby Bluetooth device via the API and the user will never be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Control use of the WebUSB API' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers a API which allows the access to connected USB devices from the browser.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: WebUSB is opening the doors for sophisticated phishing attacks that could bypass hardware-based two-factor authentication devices (e.g. Yubikey devices).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API selected from the drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Control use of the WebUSB API
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled and set to Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API, websites can no longer access connected USB devices via the API which could also prevent 2FA USB devices from working properly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure extension installation blacklist' is set to 'Enabled' ("*" for all extensions)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which extensions the users can NOT install. Extensions already installed will be removed if blacklisted.

NOTE: Chrome does offer a more granular permission based configuration called Extension management settings if blacklisting all extensions is too aggressive, which allows an organization to drill down to the exact permissions that they want to lock down. The extensions management settings requires more coordination and effort to understand what the security requirements are to block site and device permissions globally as well as more IT management to deploy the policy, the benefit would allow access to more extensions to their end-users. See link in reference section

NOTE 2: If Chrome Cleanup is Disabled, users my want to configure the extension blacklist instead of using the Extension Management option. Chrome Cleanup can help protect against malicious extensions when paired with the Extension Management policy.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This can be used to block extensions that could potentially allow remote control of the system through the browser. If there are extensions needed for securing the browser or for enterprise use these can be enabled by configuring either the policy Configure extension installation whitelist or the policy Extension management settings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value * specified.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extensions\Configure Extension Installation Blacklist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Any installed extension will be removed unless it is specified on the extension whitelist, if an organization is using any approved password managers ensure that the extension is added to the whitelist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure allowed app/extension types' is set to 'Enabled' with the values 'extension', 'hosted_app', 'platform_app', 'theme' speciﬁed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which app/extensions types are allowed.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: App or extension types that could be misused or are deprecated shall no longer be installed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with values extension, hosted_app, platform_app, theme speciﬁed:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extensions\Configure allowed app/extension types
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Extensions already installed will be removed if it's type is blacklisted and the extension itself is not whitelisted.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Configure native messaging blacklist' is set to 'Enabled' ("*" for all messaging applications)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to specify which native messaging hosts that should not be loaded.
Note: This needs to be handled carefully. If an extension is enabled, yet can't communicate with its backend code, it could behave in strange ways which results in helpdesk tickets + support load.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For consistency with Plugin and Extension policies, native messaging should be blacklisted by default, requiring explicit administrative approval of applications for whitelisting. Examples of applications that use native messaging is the 1Password password manager.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value * specified.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Native Messaging\Configure native messaging blacklist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
A blacklist value of '*' means all native messaging hosts are blacklisted unless they are explicitly listed in the whitelist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable saving passwords to the password manager' is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has a built in password manager to store passwords for users. Chrome will use local authentication to allow users to gain access to these passwords.
NOTE: If you choose to Enable this setting please review Disable synchronization of data with Google and ensure this setting is configured to meet organizational requirements.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Google Chrome password manager is ON by default and each organization should review and determine if they want to allow users to store passwords in the Browser. If another solution is used instead of the built in Chrome option then an organization should configure the setting to Disabled.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, configure the following setting to meet organizational requirements:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Password manager\Enable the password manager
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this settings is disabled, users cannot save new passwords but they may still use passwords that have been saved previously.
If this settings is enabled or not configured, users can save passwords.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Supported authentication schemes' is set to 'Enabled' (ntlm, negotiate)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies which HTTP authentication schemes are supported by Google Chrome.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Possible values are 'basic', 'digest', 'ntlm' and 'negotiate'. Basic and Digest authentication do not provide sufficient security and can lead to submission of users password in plaintext or minimal protection.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:(ntlm, negotiate).
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Policies for HTTP Authentication\Supported authentication schemes

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Choose how to specify proxy server settings' is not set to 'Enabled' with 'Auto detect proxy settings'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the functionality to configure the proxy settings by automatic discovery using WPAD (Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Protocol).

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Attackers may abuse the WPAD auto-config functionality to supply computers with a PAC file that specifies a rogue web proxy under their control.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, make sure the following UI path is not set to 'Enabled' with 'Auto detect proxy settings':
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Proxy server\Choose how to specify proxy server settings
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the policy is enabled, the proxy configuration will no longer be discovered using WPAD.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow running plugins that are outdated' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables the use of outdated plugins. By disabling this feature Chrome will not prompt the user to use an outdated plugin.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Running the most up-to-date version of a plugin can reduce the possibility of running a plugin that contains an exploit or security hole.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow running plugins that are outdated
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If you disable this setting, outdated plugins will not be used and users will not be asked for permission to run them.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google Chrome to act as a proxy between Google Cloud Print and legacy printers connected to the machine.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this option will prevent users from printing documents from unmanaged devices to an organization's printer.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Printing\Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users cannot enable the proxy, and the machine will not be allowed to share its local printers with Google Cloud Print.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Site Isolation for every site' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls is every website will load into its own process.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Chrome will load each website in its own process. So, even if a site bypasses the same-origin policy, the extra security will help stop the site from stealing your data from another website.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Site Isolation for every site
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If the policy is enabled, each site will run in its own process which will cause the system to use more memory. You might want to look at the IsolateOrigins policy setting to get the best of both worlds, isolation and limited impact for users, by using IsolateOrigins with a list of the sites you want to isolate.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow download restrictions' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Block dangerous downloads' specified.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to block certain types of downloads, and won't let users bypass the security warnings, depending on the classification of Safe Browsing.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from downloading certain types of files, and shall not be able to bypass security warnings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value 'Block dangerous downloads' selected from drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow download restrictions
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, all downloads are allowed, except for those that carry Safe Browsing warnings.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable proceeding from the Safe Browsing warning page' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google provides the Safe Browsing service. It shows a warning page when users navigate to sites that are flagged as potentially malicious.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious web pages are widely spread in the internet and pose the most significant threat to the user today. Users shall be prevented from navigating to potentially malicious web content.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable proceeding from the Safe Browsing warning page
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents users from proceeding anyway from the warning page to the malicious site. In some cases legitimate sites could be blocked and users would be prevented from accessing.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Notify a user that a browser relaunch or device restart is recommended or required' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Show a recurring prompt to the user indication that a relaunch is required' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to notify users that Google Chrome must be restarted to apply a pending update once the notification period defined by policy 'Set the time period for update notifications' is passed.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Security Updates shall be installed as soon as possible after release.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value Show a recurring prompt to the user indication that a relaunch is required specified:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Notify a user that a browser relaunch or device restart is recommended or required
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A recurring warning will be shown to the user indicating that a browser relaunch will be forced once the notification period passes. The user's session is restored after the relaunch of Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Set the time period for update notifications' is set to 'Enabled' with '86400000' (1 day) specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to set the time period, in milliseconds, over which users are notified that Google Chrome must be relaunched to apply a pending update.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Security Updates shall be installed as soon as possible after release.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value 86400000 specified:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Set the time period for update notifications
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Over this time period, the user will be repeatedly informed of the need for an update until a Browser restart is completed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Whether online OCSP/CRL checks are required for local trust anchors' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome performs revocation checking for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. If Google Chrome is unable to obtain revocation status information, such certificates will be treated as revoked ('hard-fail').

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates shall always be validated.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Whether online OCSP/CRL checks are required for local trust anchors
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A revocation check will be performed for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. if the OCSP server goes down, then this will hard-fail and prevent browsing to those sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Chrome Cleanup on Windows' is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome provides a Cleanup-feature to detect unwanted software. This feature periodically scans the system for unwanted software and will ask the user if they wish to remove it, if any been found.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Google Chrome Cleanup is ON by default and each organization should review and determine if they want to use this solutions for malware detection. If another solution is used instead of the built in Chrome option then an organization should configure the setting to Disabled.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, configure the following setting to meet organizational requirements:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Chrome Cleanup on Windows
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
if Disabled, Chrome Cleanup will no longer be able to scan the system. If users do not have a centrally managed anti-malware solution then leaving this setting enabled can help protect a system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Use built-in DNS client' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to use a built-in DNS client.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The built-in DNS client shall not be used to circumvent the usage of a trusted DNS server.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Use built-in DNS client
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to use Google DNS-over-TLS and (in future) DNS-over-HTTPS if you disable the Chrome DNS stack.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Update policy override' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Always allow updates (recommended)' or 'Automatic silent updates' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Update manages installation of available Google Chrome updates from Google. This setting allows to define whether updates are to be applied automatically. Depending on the business scenario updates shall be applied periodically or also if the user seeks for updates.

notes:notes.xhtml:p: 1 - This setting corresponds to the Always allow updates policy setting. This means that updates are always installed regardless of whether they were found via periodic silent updates or a manual update check.
3 - This setting corresponds to the Automatic silent updates only policy setting. This means updates are only installed when they are found via the periodic silent update check.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Software updates shall be applied as soon as they are available since they may include latest security patches.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value Always allow updates (recommended) or Automatic silent updates only selected from drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Update\Applications\Google Chrome\Update policy override
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Latest updates are automatically applied at least periodically.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that help improve user privacy. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within the environment since they restrict some browser functionality.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default cookies setting' is set to 'Enabled' (Keep cookies for the duration of the session)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to set whether websites are allowed to set local data. Setting local data can be either allowed for all websites or denied for all websites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Permanently stored cookies may be used for malicious intent.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Keep cookies for the duration of the session selected from the drop down.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default cookies setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, cookies will be cleared when the session closes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Default geolocation setting' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome supports to track the users' physical location using GPS, data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if you’re not using them), and your computer’s IP.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: From a privacy point of view it is not desirable to submit indicators regarding the location of the device, since the processing of this information cannot be determined. Furthermore, this may leak information about the network infrastructure around the device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location selected from the drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default geolocation setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is disabled, chrome will no longer send data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if you’re not using them), and your computer’s IP address to google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Cast' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Cast allows to send the contents of tabs, sites or the desktop from the browser to a remote display and sound system.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Cast may send the contents of tabs, sites or the desktop from the browser to non trusted devices on the local network segment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Google Cast\Enable Google Cast
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this is disabled Google Cast is not activated and the toolbar icon is not shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Block third party cookies' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows cookies to be set by web page elements that are not from the domain in the user's address bar. Enabling this feature prevents third party cookies from being set.
NOTE: Third Party Cookies and Tracking Protection are required for many business critical websites, including SalesForce and Office365.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blocking third party cookies can help protect a user's privacy by eliminating a number of website tracking cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Block third party cookies
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents cookies from being set by web page elements that are not from the domain that is in the browser's address bar.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This Setting controls anonymous reporting of usage and crash-related data about Google Chrome to Google.
NOTE: This policy is not available on Windows instances that are not joined to a Microsoft® Active Directory® domain.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymous crash/usage data can be used to identify people, companies and information, which can be considered data ex-filtration from company systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, this information is not sent to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control how Chrome Cleanup reports data to Google' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome provides a Cleanup-feature to detect unwanted software. The results of the cleanup may be shared with Google to assist with future unwanted software detection. These results will contain file metadata, automatically installed extensions and registry keys.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymous crash/usage data can be used to identify people, companies and information, which can be considered data ex-filtration from company systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Control how Chrome Cleanup reports data to Google
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Chrome Cleanup detected unwanted software, will no longer report metadata about the scan to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Browser sign in settings' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Disabled browser sign-in' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to sign-in with your Google account and use account related services like Chrome sync. It is possible to sign-in to Google Chrome with a Google account to use services like synchronization and can also be used for configuration and management of the browser.
NOTE: if an organization is a G Suite Enterprise customer they will want to leave this setting enabled so that users can sign in with Google accounts.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Since external accounts are unmanaged and potentially used to access several private computer systems and many different websites, connecting accounts via sign-in poses a security risk for the company. It interferes with the corporate management mechanisms, as well as permits an unwanted leak of corporate information and possible mixture with private, non-company data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value 'Disabled browser sign-in' selected from the drop down.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Browser sign in settings
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled the user can not sign in to the browser and use google account based services like Chrome sync.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Translate' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Content of internal web pages may be leaked to Google's translation service.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Content of internal web pages may be leaked to Google's translation service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Translate
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After disabling this feature Chrome contents of a web page are no longer sent to Google for translation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable network prediction' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Do not predict actions on any network connection' selected

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome comes with the network prediction feature which provides DNS prefetching, TCP and SSL preconnection, and prerendering of web pages. This feature might lead to connections to websites which the user has not navigated to and may never visit.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Opening connections to resources which may never be visited shall be prevented.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with value Do not predict actions on any network connection selected from the drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable network prediction
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be presented with web page predictions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable search suggestions' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers suggestions in Google Chrome's omnibox while user is typing.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using search suggestions may leak information as soon as it is typed/pasted into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable search suggestions
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The user has to send the search request actively by using the search button or hitting "Enter".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable spell checking web service' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the usage of a Google web service to help resolve spelling errors.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information typed in may be leaked to Google's spellcheck web service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable or disable spell checking web service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

After disabling this feature Chrome no longer sends the entire contents of text fields as you type in them to Google. Spell checking can still be performed using a downloaded dictionary; this policy only controls the usage of the online service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable alternate error pages' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to show suggestions for the page you were trying to reach when it is unable to connect to a web address such as 'Page Not Found'.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using navigation suggestions may leak information about the web site intended to be visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable alternate error pages
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, Chrome does no longer use a web service to help resolve navigation errors.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable synchronization of data with Google' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to synchronize browser data using Google-hosted synchronization services.
NOTE: if your organization allows synchronization of data with Google, then enabling this setting will synchronize saved passwords with Google.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser data shall not be synchronized into the Google Cloud.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable synchronization of data with Google
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, browser data will no longer sync with Google across devices/platforms allowing users to pick up where they left off.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Safe Browsing for trusted sources' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can be adjusted to allow download without Safe Browsing checks when the requested files is from a trusted source. Trusted sources can be defined using policy 'Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings'.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information requested from trusted sources shall not be sent to Google's safe browsing servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Safe Browsing for trusted sources
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled files downloaded from intranet resources will not be checked by Google Services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the feature URL-keyed anonymized data collection. This sends URLs of pages the user visits to Google to optimize its services.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymized data collection shall be disabled, since it is unclear which information exactly is sent to Google.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
anonymized data will not be sent to Google to help optimize its services

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable deleting browser and download history' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offer to delete the browser and download history using the clear browsing data menu.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If users can delete websites they have visited or files they have downloaded it will be easier for them to hide evidence that they have visited unauthorized or malicious sites.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable deleting browser and download history
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, browsing and download history cannot be deleted by using the clear browsing data menu.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations around the management, visibility and performance of Google Chrome.
This section contains recommendations that are related to remote access.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable firewall traversal from remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables the usage of STUN servers which allows remote clients to discover and connect to a machine even if they are separated by a firewall. By disabling this feature, in conjunction with filtering outgoing UDP connections, the machine will only allow connections from machines within the local network.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, remote clients can discover and connect to this machines even if they are separated by a firewall.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable firewall traversal from remote access host
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled and outgoing UDP connections are filtered by the firewall, this machine will only allow connections from client machines within the local network.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable PIN-less authentication for remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables a user to opt-out of using user-specified PIN authentication and instead pair clients and hosts during connection time.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled or not configured, users can opt to pair clients and hosts at connection time, eliminating the need to enter a PIN every time.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable or disable PIN-less authentication
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users will be required to enter PIN every time.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable the use of relay servers by the remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to use relay servers when clients are trying to connect to this machine and a direct connection is not available.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Relay servers shall not be used to circumvent firewall restrictions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable the use of relay servers by the remote access host
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, remote clients can not use relay servers to connect to this machine.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure the required domain names for remote access clients' is set to 'Enabled' with a domain defined

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows the user to configure a list of required host domain that is imposed on remote access hosts. When enabled, hosts can only be shared using accounts that are registered to the specified domains.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote assistance connections shall be restricted.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and enter a domain (e.g. nodomain.local):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Configure the required domain names for remote access clients
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, clients from the specified domains only can connect to the host.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations to help prevent and protect against unwanted loss of data. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they makes sense within the environment since they so restrict some browser functionality.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable submission of documents to Google Cloud print' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google Chrome to submit documents to Google Cloud Print for printing.
NOTE: This only affects Google Cloud Print support in Google Chrome. It does not prevent users from submitting print jobs on web sites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this option will prevent users from printing possible confidential enterprise documents through the cloud.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Printing\Enable submission of documents to Google Cloud print
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users cannot print to Google Cloud Print from the Chrome print dialog

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Import saved passwords from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls if saved passwords from the default browser can be imported.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In Chrome, passwords can be stored in plain-text and revealed by clicking the “show” button next to the password field by going to chrome://settings/passwords/.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Import saved passwords from default browser on first run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, saved passwords from other browsers are not imported.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill for credit cards' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved credit card information. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored credit card AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable AutoFill for credit cards
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, credit card AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill for addresses' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved information such as address or phone number. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored address AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable AutoFill for addresses
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.
